cell.html: Yes, Revolutionary War , Creek War , War of 1812 , First Seminole War .
cell.text: Yes, Revolutionary War , Creek War , War of 1812 , First Seminole War .

cell.html: Served at the age of 13 with the Continental Army (1780) during the Revolutionary War as a messenger, and was held as a prisoner of war (the only U.S. president to be so); served in the War of 1812 , attaining the rank of major general and became a national hero after his success at the Battle of New Orleans .
cell.text: Served at the age of 13 with the Continental Army (1780) during the Revolutionary War as a messenger, and was held as a prisoner of war (the only U.S. president to be so); served in the War of 1812 , attaining the rank of major general and became a national hero after his success at the Battle of New Orleans .
Yes, Northwest Indian War , War of 1812

cell.html: Dates of service: 1791–1798, 1812–1814. Became national hero after success at the Battle of the Thames .
cell.text: Dates of service: 1791–1798, 1812–1814. Became national hero after success at the Battle of the Thames .

cell.html: Yes, War of 1812 , Black Hawk War , Second Seminole War , and Mexican-American War ,
cell.text: Yes, War of 1812 , Black Hawk War , Second Seminole War , and Mexican-American War ,

cell.html: Became a national hero because of his achievements in the Mexican-American War .
cell.text: Became a national hero because of his achievements in the Mexican-American War .

cell.html: Successful leadership in Virginia/West Virginia region; wounded at the Battle of South Mountain
cell.text: Successful leadership in Virginia/West Virginia region; wounded at the Battle of South Mountain

cell.html: His heroic ride at the Battle of Chickamauga later helped him to be elected President.
cell.text: His heroic ride at the Battle of Chickamauga later helped him to be elected President.

context.text: List of United States Presidents by military rank - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Rank order Highest rank Branch President Combat? Service notes
[ edit ] (O-8) Major General / Rear Admiral Upper Half
List of United States Presidents by military rank
Attended West Point ; first Lieutenant General since Washington, appointed as four-star General of the Army in 1866.
[ edit ] (O-7) Brigadier General / Rear Admiral Lower Half (formerly, Commodore)
[ edit ] Table: List of United States Presidents by military rank
Yes, Mexican-American War and Civil War
Rank order Highest rank Branch President Combat? Service notes
Attended West Point ; served 1915 1952. Served stateside during World War I and as Supreme Allied Commander during World War II .

entity.htmlSnippet:
Rank orderHighest rankBranchPresidentCombat?Service notes
4Major GeneralContinental Army, United States ArmyAndrew JacksonYes, Revolutionary War, Creek War, War of 1812, First Seminole War.Served at the age of 13 with the Continental Army (1780) during the Revolutionary War as a messenger, and was held as a prisoner of war (the only U.S. president to be so); served in the War of 1812, attaining the rank of major general and became a national hero after his success at the Battle of New Orleans.
4Major GeneralUnited States ArmyWilliam H. HarrisonYes, Northwest Indian War, War of 1812Dates of service: 1791–1798, 1812–1814. Became national hero after success at the Battle of the Thames.
4Major GeneralUnited States ArmyZachary TaylorYes, War of 1812, Black Hawk War, Second Seminole War, and Mexican-American War,Became a national hero because of his achievements in the Mexican-American War.
4Brevet Major General of VolunteersUnited States Army (volunteers)Rutherford B. HayesYes, Civil WarSuccessful leadership in Virginia/West Virginia region; wounded at the Battle of South Mountain
4Major General of VolunteersUnited States Army (volunteers)James A. GarfieldYes, Civil WarHis heroic ride at the Battle of Chickamauga later helped him to be elected President.
